item.title: 1911 Handling
item.creator: clapp
item.content_encoded: When I first began shooting the 1911 in competition, I was in the Marine Corps of the early 1960s. The game was NRA Outdoor Pistol-slow, timed and rapid-one handed at 50 and 25 yards. The Corps put a lot of emphasis on the sport, with Division and Marine Corps matches conducted to select the team that went to Camp Perry for the Nationals. The season started in the spring and ended after Perry. At the beginning of the Division Matches, we spent several weeks working with a training team from Marksmanship Training Unit. Issued guns were built up before each season by RTE (Rifle Team Equipment) armorers. It was in this period of training that I was taught to handle my issued match gun in a particular way. When I mentioned this technique in another training atmosphere recently, nobody had heard of it. For a right-handed shooter I was taught to have the slide locked open and to insert a loaded magazine and fully seat it. Then, with the thumb of the left hand to hold the tip of the hammer down and release the slide lock with the right thumb. This allowed the slide to run forward, chambering a round and leaving the hammer cocked. Thus did you prepare for a string of fire. The maneuver was said to help the longevity of the trigger job by keeping the nose of the sear out of engagement as the slide slammed violently forward. It is opposite from the combat shooter, who loads his pistol by pulling the slide fully to the rear and releasing it, which insures greater slide travel-as happens when a round is fired-and better functional reliability. I am just wondering whether or not any reader remembers this or has any comment on its value.
item.excerpt_encoded: While in the Marine Corps, Wiley competed in NRA Outdoor Pistol, and was taught a peculiar way of handling a 1911.

comment.comment_content: Honestly sounds like a way to build 'muscle memory' for using two hands to do a one hand task. I'd think using the left hand only for operating the slide and then getting back into a bracing position would be a better way to lock it into muscle memory. Interesting post nonetheless, because I hadn't heard of the technique you describe. Probably with modern metallurgy, however is just overkill.

Wiley, yes our AMUs also taught us this technique, and they probably still do. Repeatedly releasing a fully locked back slide, especially with a full power hardball 1911 spring, will degrade the fine sharp edge of the hammer sear relationship, eventually requiring a trigger re-work. Especially for those requiring that clean ‘glass rod’ predictable trigger break, desired for x-ring quality shots. Whether not using the technique will eventually degrade the trigger job to the point that the hammer might someday start falling to half cock position is debatable, although I’ve seen it happen in ‘wadcutter’ match pistols, pushing the edge of a minimal match acceptable trigger weight. Most AMU armorers went to great pains to give our triggers that excellent 'clean break', worthy of competition standards. And a fine trigger job is worth its weight in Gold. So this technique of holding the trigger back served to prolong the fruits of their hard labor, to our benefit. Also yes, it does not have quite as much slide travel as manually racking the slide, but not significant enough to impair proper chambering in match competition settings. And of course most speed shooting events where tenths of a second matter, do not use the technique, to shave off precious time wherever they can. But when time permits, and the slide locks back on its own from the last round, it’s a very good technique to use for the sake of prolonging an excellent trigger job. I still use the technique to this day, though admittedly would not bother to use it in a life threatening encounter.

Got a followup to add-- In my last post here, I just realized on reflection I’ve only expounded what I’ve been taught and nothing more, without ever really questioning why. To that end, this has now made me consider the following: What is the difference between letting a slide go with or without a full magazine inserted, vs the normal operation of the gun? After all, with every shot taken, the slide impacts the frame and rebounds with the same force as manually letting it go anyways. So why bother holding the hammer back manually, if your next string of 10 shots or more might still eventually degrade your sear anyway?? On realizing this, it might make one think it isn’t worth the effort. So Is this just an ‘old wive’s tale’ then? And yet as a competitive shooter, we would put many thousands of rounds through our guns in practice before ever needing our triggers re-worked. Well, not being a certified gunsmith, I went out and consulted a few top tier ones and came back with a more definitive answer which is Yes, this holding the trigger back technique does matter, and here’s why. The concept is referred to as ‘trigger bounce’. First of all, there is a difference in how violently the slide slams forward with a full magazine inserted vs without, due to some energy being absorbed overcoming the friction of the round stripping off and chambering, and the extractor engaging the cartridge rim. This serves to absorb some of that shock, which is no surprise. And the second part is, that letting a slide go while loose in the hand is a different matter, vs holding tight in a formal shooting stance. A very light handed grip allows enough inertia for the sear to bounce harder against the cocked hammer with a greater impact. Enough to make a difference in the life of your trigger job. And in most competitive shooting events, the fully supported hold has not yet been taken when letting the slide go forward. So there you have it. And in the third place, the issue of the hammer ever falling to half cock is another story, having more to do with trigger weight. The lighter the trigger you have, the more competent the gunsmith you’ll need to ensure the trigger job is up to that. And also in response to Clay’s post, you’re probably right about this being overkill nowadays, with modern metallurgy. Our armorers worked with milspec parts, which were only surface hardened. Once a milspec hammer or sear is worked on and improved, some of that surface hardness is taken away, and so that trigger might eventually need a re-work after a few thousand rounds. There are many excellent aftermarket triggers available nowadays, EDM machined to exacting tolerances, then hardened through and through. These ones, if your satisfied with them, will probably never need this technique to preserve them. Good point to make. Okay, that’s all I can contribute here, hope its enough.
Minor correction to first post. I meant to say 'this technique of holding the hammer back...', not holding back the trigger, which is very bad to do while letting the slide go. Sorry for that typo...

Gotta remember, Wiley, back in the '60 was 50 years ago. The Marine Corps was still using WWII and earlier issue 1911's. Even the new ones were being made on machinery that was state of the art in 1917. The 1911 means that that good old venerable pistol first saw light of day 103 years ago. You're showing your age. I was in ten years before you and every 1911 we had could now be considered a collectible.

Many years ago a trigger job would include a procedure where two thirds of the hammer notch would be filed away leaving only the center one third of the hammer to catch the sear. Military armors used this technique when trigger jobs were first being developed for bulls eye shooting. The sear engagement 'fit' was easier to accomplish. The downside of this was chipping off the notch when letting the slide go full energy on the notch. Thus the old school method of thumb on the hammer and first finger on the slide release. Holding pressure on the trigger holds the disconnect in position when the slide is released. The pistol will not fire with the disconnect engaged.

The Small Arms Firing School that I attended taught us to hold the hammer down with the left thumb and release the slide with the left fore finger to prevent hammer follow and extend the life of the trigger job. This was when they quit holding the trigger back and releasing the slide.

AMU Vet, I caught the trigger statement off the bat, but knew what you were saying and meaning. Being the unit Marksmanship coordinator for an Combat Engineer Co., Taking troops to FT. Knox for the State Rifle teem, I did get to help some with the Berreta 92. and noticed one troop operating the slide release with his 'off hand' which seemed odd at the time. He must have been traind to do so as now the slide is released with the hand holding the weapon, being operatable from either side.By the way, under combat situation, one need to use the onehanded method as his off hand may be doing something else. as retriving another slid or even injured. Good post.

As a L/Cpl in the Marines, I was taught the same technique while assigned to the 2d MAW MTU & member of the pistol team in 1988. The reason was to prevent to the hammer from following the slide upon loading, and to protect the sear. An alternative technique was to squeeze & hold the trigger when releasing the slide. Now as a MSgt in the Air National Guard, and the NCOIC of my base pistol team, I teach my bullseye shooters to hold the hammer back with our team guns ~ which where were hand-built by the AF Gunsmith shop 20-30 years ago. I do the same thing with my new Les Baer hardball gun.

item.title: The Armed Citizen® January 28, 2014
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: Residents were at home watching a movie around 11:20 p.m. when several men forced their way into the home through the front door. One of the residents opened fire on the intruders causing them to flee. One suspect was killed at the scene and another was later found with fatal gunshot wounds in the parking lot of a nearby animal hospital. Police reported that it appeared the suspect's body was dumped there as the others fled from the home-invasion-gone-bad. None of the residents were harmed during the ordeal. (The Florida Times-Union, Jacksonville, FL, 6/20/13) A 14-year-old boy was home alone in Pueblo, Colo., when three intruders broke in through the back door. According to reports, the boy heard someone enter and armed himself, and was faced with three intruders whom he opened fire on. He told police he believes he hit one of the intruders, who immediately fled. It was said that the home's power had been cut before the backdoor had been kicked in. Police are still searching for the suspects and keeping an eye on local hospitals for any gunshot wound victims. (Gunssavelives.net, Pueblo, Colo., 1/16/14) From The Armed Citizen Archives April 1974: A would-be burglar broke a plate glass window in a West Plains, Mo., gas station early one morning, prompting owner Leon Keller to open fire with his 12-gauge shotgun. The prowler fled, apparently untouched by the single buckshot blast. (The Daily Quill, West Plains, Mo.)
item.excerpt_encoded: Read three more amazing stories of self-defense in the latest online edition of The Armed Citizen®.
